A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: It's almost as if Rian Johnson has never seen a Star Wars movie\, let alone a Star Wars film featuring Luke before. The primary characteristics of Luke Skywalker are optimism\, pacifism\, a deep need to help others\, and an incredible belief in redemption. Luke Skywalker in this film was none of these things. Personality-wise\, Luke Skywalker in this film had as much in common with Luke in the original trilogy as he has in common with the Emperor\, or a plank of wood. Even Mark Hamill's incredible acting talents cannot save this complete and utter departure from the original character and the total lack of anyone giving a moment's thought to character continuity. \n\nAnd the rest of the film besides Luke? Boring\, circuitous\, disrespectful to anything set up by The Force Awakens\, and a less enjoyable watch than Attack of the Clones\, which\, let me remind everyone\, has a pear floating scene. At least Attack of the Clones I can enjoy for being unintentionally funny and for the utter charm of Obi Wan. The Last Jedi is the first Star Wars film I regret seeing. As one wise soul on the ether of the internet said \"I'd rather see a Jar Jar origin film.\"
